message: if the OP doesn't want to pay $45 for TM, they probably won't want to pay for coda.
I think TextMate is not worth the fee until it's significantly updated. I paid for it and loved it for a few years, but it is way behind in many respects.  I switched back to emacs.

MacVIM is pretty comparable to textmate assuming you take the time needed to find, install, and configure a bunch of vim plugins, I switched about 6 months ago and haven't looked back

also using emacs or vim gets you a bunch of programmer hipster cool points which is the most important thing to consider when choosing an editor

I used to be in love with coda, but after tuning up my MacVIM with https://github.com/carlhuda/janus I can do way more than before without leaving vim.

gVim
For mandatory reasons - Eclipse.
@andrewbadr Honestly, they both have their uses. Some things about Vim were amazing, i.e. modal keybindings are fantastic. Emacs just fit my development philosophy.

@mrtazz It's all about appreciating the Zen of Emacs. Re-bind your capslock to control, which is trivial to do on any operating system now. I used this cheat-sheet, http://karl-voit.at/vim-emacs-cheatsheet_of_freezing_hell.txt, at the beginning and I customized my emacs using technomancy's starter-kit, which I have forked and heavily customized for my Python development (https://github.com/mahmoudimus/.emacs.d/tree/mu).

After two weeks of some productivity losses, I was able to re-gain efficiency and haven't looked back since.
@mahmoudimus thanks. Maybe this time I'll stick with it a bit longer.
Aquamacs or eclipse.
I'm a TextMate loyalist but I've just checked out Kod based on a few suggestions above and wow, I'm pretty impressed!

I used vim for everything for years, in the last month or so I've picked up textmate and holy wow its awesome. I never understood why so many of my colleagues liked osx so much for development (Linux user here) until now.

Eclipse, NetBeans are awesome solutions at the right price. I liked Textmate way back when -- still use it sometimes. Once I found NetBeans a couple years back, I was very pleased -- especially for $0.00. But now that Oracle has dropped Ruby support from NetBeans, I'm using RubyMine for most of my day-to-day. Been happy overall with the switch.

Isn't this discussion boring the hell out of you already? In the last 2 months I have seen thousands of these. In blogs, SO, reddit, convore, even linkedin. Check python group and you'll see. There are finite number of editors and I think all are covered. Same goes for the IDEs. Stop it once and for all. Or at least make 3-6 months long break so that new features are added in the editors.
